snippet: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a likely candidate for the Republican Party’s presidential nomination in 2016, was forced on Thursday to address an act of political revenge by his staff that has threatened his political career.
abstract: New Jersey Gov Chris Christie, in remarkable day of political drama, tries to control damage from revelations that his administration ordered closings of lanes at George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee in September in act of political revenge; Christie, a likely Republican presidential contender for 2016, fires top aide, cuts ties with longtime political adviser and repeatedly apologizes in nearly two-hour news conference.

byline.original: By KATE ZERNIKE and MARC SANTORA
byline.contributor: Kate Zernike reported from Trenton, and Marc Santora from New York. Michael Barbaro, Sarah Maslin Nir and William K. Rashbaum contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a likely candidate for the Republican Party’s presidential nomination in 2016, was forced on Thursday to address an act of political revenge by his staff that has threatened his political career.

headline.main: ‘Very Sad’ Chris Christie Extends Apology in Bridge Scandal
